abstracts.cdata!:
The First Forestry Project for Burundi
            achieved a largely satisfactory overall outcome. The
            physical objectives were largely achieved. The quality of
            management and of output was good, and project supervision
            was rated problem-free or with only minor problems
            throughout the project cycle. The main implementation
            problems were occasional late availability of counterpart
            funds, land conflicts with the population, and the fact that
            the project was mainly implemented by expatriates. The two
            main objectives of the project were to strengthen the
            Forestry Department and to promote tree planting. Training
            was provided for some 80 middle-level forestry technicians,
            and the project also financed vehicles and a headquarters
            building for the Forestry Department. However, on the higher
            or professional level, the project was less successful; it
            only provided one two-year scholarship due to lack of
            candidates. Regarding tree planting, the project established
            81 nurseries which produced seedlings from which communal
            and individual plantations were established. The
            project's main sustainability problem during the first
            phase was that it was mainly being implemented by
            expatriates. However, the project was Burundized half-way
            through the second phase in December 1988. Sustainability of
            the project nurseries is reliant on the Forestry Department
            becoming more active about marketing the output from its
            industrial plantations. The primary lesson learned is that
            obtaining land for industrial plantations in a densely
            populated country like Burundi occasionally led to conflicts
            with farmers and pastoralists. The second phase of the
            project adjusted to this lesson by reducing the area of new
            industrial plantations while placing greater emphasis on
            agro-sylvo pastoralism.
